{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3576884,"name":"Scott W","username":"Programming4907","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/programming4907/{size}/168313_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-01T18:05:17.624Z","cooked":"

I find the occasional command scheduler loop overrun warnings to be unhelpful and they’re cluttering up the driver station console log.

We regularly use the logging in AdvantageKit to track CPU usage anyway, and we can clearly see any instance of a loop overrun in the graph.

Is there a way to disable the loop overrun warning that gets printed to the console?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-04-01T18:05:17.624Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":137.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497720,"topic_slug":"can-the-loop-overrun-warning-be-disabled","display_username":"Scott W","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50699,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-the-loop-overrun-warning-be-disabled/497720/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3576907,"name":"Val","username":"Otter502","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/otter502/{size}/245799_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-01T18:23:01.803Z","cooked":"

I don’t believe there is?
The loop overruns are printed out here (I think?) and there doesn’t seem to be a conditional which stops it.

image1041×641 41 KB

CommandScheduler.run()

I’m genuinely curious though, since we don’t use Akit, with the Akit CPU usage can you see how much each command / subsystem uses?

Hope this helps!

I guess I’ll just leave this here.

Please use responsibly with appropriate alternative measures to detect loop overruns (like AdvantageKit loop cycle logging). One of the benefits of this approach is that you can still have the messages be printed for large loop overruns even if you don’t need to see every cycle longer than 20ms.

Otter502:

I’m genuinely curious though, since we don’t use Akit, with the Akit CPU usage can you see how much each command / subsystem uses?

No, but when we have a loop overrun the message rarely points to a subsystem being the problem (none of the printed times is very large). We typically see loop overruns from Java class loading, garbage collection, and loading things like paths from the flash drive. None of that has anything to do with the commands or subsystems.

Another good way to find what’s causing excessive CPU usage is VisualVM.
